abstracts.cdata!:
Ratings for the Transport Infrastructure
            Investment Project (TIIP) for Madagascar were as follows:
            outcomes were moderately satisfactory, risk to development
            outcome was high, Bank performance was moderately
            satisfactory, and Borrower performance was moderately
            satisfactory. Some lessons learned included: two of the
            reasons why the transport sector reforms in general and the
            ports and airports concession in particular were not
            entirely successful were: (i) the high-level political
            interference in the sector, and (ii) the overambitious
            target to concession all the ports and airports in the
            country. The instability risk raises the question about the
            adequacy of the Adaptable Program Loan (APL) instruments
            which were designed to support a long-term transport sector
            transformational agenda. The choice of the Project
            Development Objective (PDO) indicators should take into
            account the type of data which can be collected during
            implementation. The Monitoring and Evaluation (M and E)
            system of the TIIP did not make clear distinction between
            the achievements under: (a) the standalone project; (b) the
            APL series; and (c) the government long-term program. As a
            result, it was not easy to assess the achievements, the
            outcomes and the impacts of the project. Some sections had
            to be rehabilitated or reconstructed contributing to a
            higher cost than anticipated. Proactivity and innovation
            during project implementation are necessary to adapting to
            an ever changing environment. While supporting railway
            concession, ensure enabling environment and fair intermodal competition.

repnme.cdata!:
Madagascar - Transport Infrastructure
            Investment Project : restructuring

abstracts.cdata!:
The objective of the Transport
            Infrastructure Investment Project for Madagascar is to
            rehabilitate the country's major transport
            infrastructure in order to reduce transport cost and to
            facilitate trade. The changes include: (i) extend the
            closing date to allow completion of activities that got
            delayed due to the political crisis; and (ii) reallocate the
            projects' proceeds to use up the credits'
            remaining funds (US$852,361.28) to finance some additional
            activities. The borrower has also requested to include a
            disbursement grace period to enable the payment of eligible
            expenditures up to four months after the project's
            closing date. However, due to the very limited amount of
            undisbursed funds, the Bank will only consider the project
            fund's reallocation proceed and deal with the
            disbursement grace period in a separate letter to the Borrower.

display_title.display_title:
Madagascar - Transport
            Infrastructure Investment Project : restructuring (Vol. 2) :
            Data sheet

repnme.cdata!:
Madagascar - Transport Infrastructure
            Investment Project : restructuring

abstracts.cdata!:
The objective of the Transport
            Infrastructure Investment Project for Madagascar is to
            rehabilitate the country's major transport
            infrastructure in order to reduce transport cost and to
            facilitate trade. The additional activities are unlikely to
            require any change in the project objective. The extension
            of the closing date is being processed as a level two
            restructuring, requiring the Vice President's approval
            since it involves a cumulative extension of the closing date
            of more than two years from the original closing date. This
            extension will allow for: 1) the completion of the suspended
            works contracts as a result of the disbursement freeze due
            to the crisis, in order to reinforce the outcome of our
            investments in railways infrastructure; 2) the payment of
            arrears for works, goods, and services for contracts
            committed after March 17, 2009, and whose corresponding
            services have been duly completed, and 3) the use of the
            remaining funds of SDR2.87 millions, after the payment of
            the two above-mentioned items, to finance transport
            equipment and infrastructure, for unfinished road surface
            layer, slope stabilizations, and some consultancy services.

display_title.display_title:
Madagascar - Transport
            Infrastructure Investment Project : restructuring (Vol. 2) :
            Data sheet

            Investment Project : restructuring

The objective of the Transport
            Infrastructure Investment Project for Madagascar is to
            rehabilitate the country's major transport
            infrastructure in order to reduce transport cost and to
            facilitate trade. The additional activities are unlikely to
